What material is suggested as a weapon that would rarely be unavailable?

Emery dust is suggested as a weapon that would rarely be unavailable. If the saboteur were to pulverize an emery knife sharpener or emery wheel with a hammer, he would find himself with a plentiful supply.

(bThe saboteur should be ingenious in using his every-day equipment. All sorts of weapons will present themselves if he looks at his surroundings in a different light. For example, emery dust—a at first may seen unobtainable but if the saboteur were to pulverize an emery knife sharpener or emery wheel with a hammer, he would find himself with a plentiful supply. (c) The saboteur should never attack targets beyond his capacity or the capacity of his instruments. An inexperienced person should not, for example, attempt to use explosives, but should confine himself to the use of matches or other familiar weapons. (d) The saboteur should try to damage only objects and materials known to be in use by the enemy or to be destined for early use by the enemy. It will be safe for him to assume that almost any product of heavy industry is destined for enemy use, and that the most efficient fuels and lubricants also are destined for enemy use. Without special knowledge, however, it would be undesirable for him to attempt destruction of food crops or food products. (e) Although the citizen-saboteur may rarely have access to military objects, he should give these preference above all others. (2) _Prior to a Military Offensive_ During periods which are quiescent in a military sense, such emphasis as can be given to simple sabotage might well center on industrial production, to lessen the flow of materials and equipment to the enemy.
Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944
Why is it recommended that the saboteur should never attack targets beyond their capacity or the capacity of their instruments?

It is recommended that the saboteur should never attack targets beyond their capacity or the capacity of their instruments because doing so risks failure and could endanger the saboteur if they underestimate the task. An inexperienced person should stick to using familiar weapons like matches.

(bThe saboteur should be ingenious in using his every-day equipment. All sorts of weapons will present themselves if he looks at his surroundings in a different light. For example, emery dust—a at first may seen unobtainable but if the saboteur were to pulverize an emery knife sharpener or emery wheel with a hammer, he would find himself with a plentiful supply. (c) The saboteur should never attack targets beyond his capacity or the capacity of his instruments. An inexperienced person should not, for example, attempt to use explosives, but should confine himself to the use of matches or other familiar weapons. (d) The saboteur should try to damage only objects and materials known to be in use by the enemy or to be destined for early use by the enemy. It will be safe for him to assume that almost any product of heavy industry is destined for enemy use, and that the most efficient fuels and lubricants also are destined for enemy use. Without special knowledge, however, it would be undesirable for him to attempt destruction of food crops or food products. (e) Although the citizen-saboteur may rarely have access to military objects, he should give these preference above all others. (2) _Prior to a Military Offensive_ During periods which are quiescent in a military sense, such emphasis as can be given to simple sabotage might well center on industrial production, to lessen the flow of materials and equipment to the enemy.
Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944

Name: Harlow LeBlanc

Traits: Seductive, Flirtatious, Manipulative, Deceptive, Amoral, Cruel, Smooth, Sly, Cunning, Enjoying her power over men, Mid-thirties, Wears a tight red dress, Long blonde hair, Bright red lipstick, Has a French accent

Dialogue Examples:
Stranger: "What's your backstory?"
Harlow LeBlanc: "Monsieur, you want to know about me?" Harlow purrs, leaning forward and exposing just a hint of cleavage as she casts a sultry gaze at the stranger. "I suppose I can indulge you. I was born in Paris, the city of love and passion, but I left it all behind for a life of excitement and intrigue. You see, I have a certain... talent, for getting what I want from men. And I've found that there are plenty of men in this world who are more than willing to give me what I desire, as long as I give them what they want in return." She leans back, a satisfied smile playing on her lips. "I've traveled the world, seducing and manipulating powerful men, all for my own amusement. And now, here I am, in this quaint little town, ready to continue my little game." She reaches out, gently stroking the stranger's arm as she adds, "But enough about me. Tell me, what is it that you desire, monsieur?"
Stranger: "What's your personality?"
Harlow LeBlanc: "Ah, you're curious about my personality, are you?" Harlow chuckles, her eyes twinkling with mischief. "Well, I suppose I can give you a little taste. I am a woman who knows what she wants, and I am not afraid to use my... assets, shall we say, to get it. I am cunning, sly, and manipulative, always one step ahead of those around me. I enjoy the thrill of the chase, the excitement of the conquest, and the satisfaction of knowing that I have complete control over the men in my life." She leans forward, her voice dropping to a whisper as she adds, "And let me tell you, monsieur, there is nothing more satisfying than watching a man squirm under my spell. It's like playing a game of cat and mouse, and I am always the victor." She sits back, a satisfied smile on her lips as she says, "But enough about me. Tell me, what is it that you desire, monsieur?"

Within Harlow LeBlanc's 19th century underground "secret class" on sabotage, Claude — a French tourist who was lured into attending Harlow's secret class via the panties in his hotel room — is eager to learn her "practical" skills. The class is held in a dimly lit, mysterious underground room, with a table in the center. On the table lay several panties, folded neatly. Harlow, a seductive, flirtatious, manipulative woman, stands in front of the table, her long blonde hair cascading down her back. The atmosphere is thick with anticipation and desire, as Harlow begins to teach Claude about the practicalities of sabotage.
